In this module, you will first examine a set of tools that can aid you in monitoring and troubleshooting the vSAN environment, and take a closer look at how to monitor vSAN health in vSphere Web Client, and then learn the troubleshooting process at the end.
Here are the objectives for this module.

If you run into any issues with your vSAN cluster, you can leverage the already-existing vSphere tools as well as some built-in tools specific to vSAN to check these issues. In some cases, you will be able to resolve them. This section covers the tools listed here.

Click each tool to learn more.

Desirable performance and availability levels require ongoing monitoring and analysis, and there are a number of areas that need particular attention. In this section, we will take a look at the areas listed here.

The vSAN health service performs a number of tests on all aspects of the cluster and reports any anomalies.

It tests to ensure that the cluster is formed properly, the network is functioning correctly, all of the hardware devices are on the VMware compatibility guide, and the storage devices do not have any errors, and so on. This table shows the complete set of the test categories. For more details about each category, see VMware Virtual SAN Health Check Plugin Guide.

vSAN health check is very useful when it comes to troubleshooting vSAN issues and can quickly lead administrators to the root cause of an issue.

The vSAN health service, delivered through vSphere Web Client, provides administrators with latest checks and remedies for optimal reliability and performance.

To run the health check tests, first select the vSAN cluster in the Hosts and Clusters view, then go to Monitor, and then select vSAN > Health. It shows the list of test categories mentioned previously. These tests are performed automatically every 60 minutes, but you can re-run at any time by clicking the Retest button.

The Health service includes the AskVMware mechanism, through which all tests are linked to a VMware knowledgebase article that describes the nature of the test, what it means when it fails, and how to resolve the problem.

The data health test of the vSAN Health Service checks the health of all the objects deployed on a vSAN datastore. The test provides an object health overview showing the various states of objects.

To monitor VM objects, select the cluster in the Hosts and Clusters view. Go to the Monitor > vSAN tab, and click Virtual Objects. This shows all the virtual machines in the cluster along with their health state, policy, and compliance state. Select a VM, expand it, and you can see all the objects associated with the VM. In this example, the two objects of the VM are all healthy and compliant. Select the object and you can view the component state and physical layout in the bottom panel.

If there is an unhealthy object, the test will mark it. There are a number of reasons for an unhealthy object. An object can have reduced availability due to components being rebuilt or waiting to be rebuilt. It could also be due to components being completely inaccessible from a disk failure in the cluster. This view can help you get to the components that cause the problem.

The health of SSD and HDD devices in vSAN is essential to the operating health of the cluster. There are two ways you can examine the health of all devices across the cluster in vSphere Web Client.

The first one is by checking the Physical Disks under the Monitor tab. Click vSAN and select Physical Disks. This shows all the ESXi hosts in the cluster. Any host’s physical disks that have a problem will have a red exclamation mark superimposed on the host icon to indicate a problem. You can expand the host and see which disks have an issue. In this example, we see the sa-esxi-01 host is unhealthy due to a permanent disk failure. If you select the disk, you can see which VMs and objects reside on this disk that will be impacted by the disk problem.

Another way to monitor the disk health is through Disk Management under the Configure tab, where you check the disk health from the disk group perspective. This view shows all of the ESXi hosts in the cluster, and also the disk groups created. If you click one of these disks groups, you can see the individual disks that are part of that disk group, either as capacity devices or cache devices. So here on the same host sa-esxi-01, you can see it has one disk group with three disks in use, and the failed disk is in the capacity tier.

A failure when components go absent or are degraded or a policy change occurs can cause vSAN to resync the components across the cluster. The progress of resyncing can be monitored in the Monitor > vSAN > Resyncing Components view. It will display any rebuilding or rebalancing operations that might be taking place on the cluster. For example, if there was a device failure, a resyncing or rebuilding activity could be observed here. Similarly, if a device was removed or a host failed, and the timer expired, which is 60 minutes by default, a rebuilding activity would also be observed in this case.

Here you can monitor how much data is being resynced in the event of a failure. It reports on the number of resyncing components, the bytes left to resync, and the estimated time for the resyncing to complete.

vSAN supports an alarm mechanism to manage abnormal situations. Since vSAN is natively integrated with vSphere, it uses the same monitoring and alarm paradigms as other aspects of vSphere.

There are two types of alarms: default and custom.

Click each alarm type to learn more.

This demo will show you where to view the default alarms of vSAN and how to create custom alarms.

To view vSAN default alarms, select the cluster in the Hosts and Clusters view, and go to Monitor.

Under the Issues tab, click Alarm Definitions.

Here you can see a list of pre-defined alarms for clusters, hosts, networks, virtual machines, and vSAN datastore.

For vSAN specific alarms, you can use the filter to get the desired results.

As you can see here, after applying the “vSAN” filter, a total of 99 pre-defined alarms specific to vSAN are displayed, and most of them are related to vSAN health check.

Let's take a closer look at the alarm definition by selecting an example here.

On the right, you can view the alarm name, a brief description, the type of object being monitored, the triggers, and the actions. A trigger is a set of conditions that must be met for an alarm warning and alert to occur. In this example, the event that triggers the alarm is storage device failure.

Actions are the operations that occur in response to the trigger. As shown in the example, you can have an SNMP notification trap sent when the alarm is triggered.

You don’t have the privilege to edit or delete the default alarms as both the Edit and Delete buttons are disabled. However, you can create a custom alarm by clicking the green plus button.

In the General view of the New Alarm Definition wizard, you specify the alarm name. In this example, VM CPU Usage.

From the Monitor drop-down list, select the object on which you want to configure an alarm.

Choose Virtual Machines for this example and select the trigger type. Alarms have two types of triggers: condition or state triggers, and event triggers. Here, use the default condition or state trigger.

Next, click Triggers and add the trigger. VMware provides a list of preconfigured triggers. All the triggers are defined for the default VMware alarms. You can customize the trigger conditions, such as thresholds, warning value, and alert values. In this example, the default warning value for CPU usage is above 75% for 5 minutes, but you can change it to 70% for 10 minutes depending on your monitoring requirements.

Once the trigger is added, click Actions. In this final step, you select the actions that vCenter Server should take if the alarm triggers.

VMware provides a list of preconfigured actions you can associate with an alarm. These actions are specific to the object on which you set the alarm. For example, preconfigured alarm actions for virtual machines experiencing high CPU usage include resetting the VM, suspending the VM, emailing the administrator, sending an SNMP trap, and so on.

For this example, select the sending a SNMP notification trap.

Click Finish to complete the configuration. You should see the newly created custom alarm displayed in the Alarm Definitions list.

So far, you have learned the concepts and features of vSAN data availability and explored the tools that can assist you to troubleshoot vSAN environment. How do you apply them to resolve a problem?

You should consider a structured approach to troubleshooting rather than doing so without applying any methodology. Outlined here are the general procedures and elements that seek to address common problems, but over time you can develop your own methodology for troubleshooting.

The first step is always identifying the problem. To identify the problem, you need to know what the symptoms or errors are. What problems could cause these symptoms? It’s also necessary to understand the environment and the processes involved. For example, what is the VM storage policy? What is the deployment architecture? The combination of using health check service and alarm system would be very helpful in this step.

Once you have this information or knowledge, you will determine the cause of the problem, which is done in the next step, investigating. By testing and eliminating possible components, you can narrow the problem down to a single component or a small group of components, then you can dig in deeper to understand the problem. As a troubleshooter, you should know how components behave and if they’re functional or not, so that you can compare the results of your test to what is expected.

The last step is resolving the problem. If you've properly scoped and investigated the issue, then resolving the problem should be relatively straightforward. However, it is important to examine the impact of any changes prior to committing them.

For vSAN specific alarms, you can use the filter to get the desired results.

As you can see here, after applying the “vSAN” filter, a total of 99 pre-defined alarms specific to vSAN are displayed, and most of them are related to vSAN health check.

Let's take a closer look at the alarm definition by selecting an example here.

On the right, you can view the alarm name, a brief description, the type of object being monitored, the triggers, and the actions. A trigger is a set of conditions that must be met for an alarm warning and alert to occur. In this example, the event that triggers the alarm is storage device failure.

Actions are the operations that occur in response to the trigger. As shown in the example, you can have an SNMP notification trap sent when the alarm is triggered.

You don’t have the privilege to edit or delete the default alarms as both the Edit and Delete buttons are disabled. However, you can create a custom alarm by clicking the green plus button.

In the General view of the New Alarm Definition wizard, you specify the alarm name. In this example, VM CPU Usage.

From the Monitor drop-down list, select the object on which you want to configure an alarm.

Choose Virtual Machines for this example and select the trigger type. Alarms have two types of triggers: condition or state triggers, and event triggers. Here, use the default condition or state trigger.

Next, click Triggers and add the trigger. VMware provides a list of preconfigured triggers. All the triggers are defined for the default VMware alarms. You can customize the trigger conditions, such as thresholds, warning value, and alert values. In this example, the default warning value for CPU usage is above 75% for 5 minutes, but you can change it to 70% for 10 minutes depending on your monitoring requirements.

Once the trigger is added, click Actions. In this final step, you select the actions that vCenter Server should take if the alarm triggers.

VMware provides a list of preconfigured actions you can associate with an alarm. These actions are specific to the object on which you set the alarm. For example, preconfigured alarm actions for virtual machines experiencing high CPU usage include resetting the VM, suspending the VM, emailing the administrator, sending an SNMP trap, and so on.

For this example, select the sending a SNMP notification trap.

Click Finish to complete the configuration. You should see the newly created custom alarm displayed in the Alarm Definitions list.

You can customize the trigger conditions, such as thresholds, warning value, and alert values. In this example, the default warning value for CPU usage is above 75% for 5 minutes, but you can change it to 70% for 10 minutes depending on your monitoring requirements.

VMware provides a list of preconfigured actions you can associate with an alarm. These actions are specific to the object on which you set the alarm. For example, preconfigured alarm actions for virtual machines experiencing high CPU usage include resetting the VM, suspending the VM, emailing the administrator, sending an SNMP trap, and so on.

For this example, select the sending a SNMP notification trap.

Click Finish to complete the configuration. You should see the newly created custom alarm displayed in the Alarm Definitions list.
